title: How to Organize the Pots and Pans Cabinet

steps.headline: Remove your pots and pans from the cabinet.
steps.description: Before you can organize your cookware, you need to take inventory of what you have. Lay the contents of your cupboard out flat on the kitchen floor, table, or counter.

steps.headline: Get rid of cookware you don’t use.
steps.description: If you never use a pot or pan, having it in your cupboard only adds unnecessary clutter. Toss or recycle cookware in bad shape, including any pots and pans that are warped, dented, peeling, or scratched. Damaged items may not cook food evenly or thoroughly. Many people find they don’t actually need three of the same size pan, so consider getting rid of duplicates to make more space. If it’s still in good shape and you just never use it, consider donating it.

steps.headline: Make sure that each lid corresponds to a pot or pan.
steps.description: You can use a pot or pan without a lid, but a lid that goes to nothing isn’t useful. If a lid has a loose handle, try tightening it first. If you can’t tighten the lid, it might come off in the middle of cooking, so you should probably get rid of it.

steps.headline: Move cookware you rarely use to another location.
steps.description: If you have a large roaster that you only use around the holidays, store it in an easy-to-get-to spot in your basement or closet. It’s best to reserve kitchen cabinet space for the items you need frequently.

steps.headline: Clean and line the cabinet while everything is out.
steps.description: Who knows when you’ll next have a totally empty cabinet! Wipe down the surfaces with a damp rag and then let it dry with the door open. Once it’s dry, you can lay down paper or rubber shelf lining. Rubber lining is especially useful to keep your cookware from moving around too much, so it doesn’t get scratched up.

steps.headline: Avoid stacking frequently-used pots and pans.
steps.description: If you use your trusty 10-inch skillet three times a week while preparing dinner, it doesn’t make much sense to have it buried deep underneath a bunch of other pots and pans. By setting the items you use most frequently off to the side instead of stacking them with the rest, you can save yourself the hassle of digging around in the cabinet every day.

steps.headline: Cushion stacked cookware with paper plates.
steps.description: You’re going to have to stack some of the pots and pans, so place paper plates in between to keep them from getting scratched. This is especially important for nonstick pans, because you don’t want to scratch the finish. You can also use fabric or silicon as a protective layer. Put your heaviest items on the bottom shelf.

steps.headline: Put your pots in a corner cabinet with a Lazy Susan if you have one.
steps.description: Lazy Susan’s allow you to spin the rack and easily access pots and pans hidden in the back. If you have a cabinet like this that you’re currently using for something else, consider if it would make more sense to have the pans there instead⁠—it’s up to you!

steps.headline: Use wire racks to take advantage of vertical space in your cabinet.
steps.description: Racks with stands create more vertical space, allowing you to “stack” your cookware without actually stacking pieces inside one another. One trick is to store your flat items vertically, rather than horizontally, using a dish rack. Organizing these items vertically saves you the hassle of digging through a large pile of baking pans later on. If you need to keep a frequently-used item separate, place a single-layer metal rack above your other pots and pans and place the special pan on top.

steps.headline: Hang a pan to the side, if you have a large enough cupboard.
steps.description: This offers you another way to keep a frequently-used pan separate from the rest. Fix a hook to the side of your cupboard and hang a narrow pan from it. When you’re buying hooks, make sure they are strong enough to support the weight of your pan. A plastic adhesive hook will probably work, but you might need something stronger. Hanging on the side of the cabinet only works with narrow pans, since large pots poke out into the cabinet too much.

steps.headline: Install a door-mounted lid rack if you need more space for lids.
steps.description: These wire racks are specially designed to store lids vertically. Place a hook on the inside of your cupboard door and mount the rack onto the hook. You can also make your own lid rack by mounting adjustable curtain rods onto eye hooks on the inside of your door. The handle of the lid will rest on top of the curtain rod, holding the lid in place.
